captions.text:
You know, the first few weeks of January are
always slow ones &#39;cos everyone&#39;s still picking

the bits of candy cane out of their teeth
and chasing the last few New Years partygoers

out of the kitchen cupboards, but it&#39;s a waste
of energy getting frustrated at the release
schedule.

If it&#39;s decided it&#39;s on a break let&#39;s do the
same and just have a super casual time talking

about whatever games we&#39;re playing without
fretting about silly things like being relevant

or funny or interesting or getting to the
bathroom before I piss my pants.
So here goes.

Hi, I&#39;m Yahtzee Croshaw, super casual game
reviewer.
What&#39;s that, games industry?
No new games of interest?
That&#39;s cool, we&#39;re all super cas here.
Have a fun size Twix.
Yeah, so I finally finished Celeste this week.

I&#39;ve been playing it super cas style for about
an hour every three months.
And yeah, it certainly is a game.
It was okay.

I dunno, the way people were banging on about
it all year I was expecting it to fire streamers
and ticker tape out of its nipples.

Is this like the Senua&#39;s Sacrifice thing where
the main character has a mental illness and

therefore it&#39;s a masterpiece and if you think
otherwise you&#39;re Hitler?
Oh, you ARE Hitler?
Well that&#39;s cool, I&#39;m super cas.
Have a Twix.
Heyyyyy.

And over Christmas I did a super cas stream
of Katamari Damacy Reroll, the rerelease of

the original PS2 game that recently came out
in a super cas kind of way, and what surprised

me was how many young people in the stream
chat pulled out their pacifiers and mentioned
they&#39;d never heard of Katamari Damacy before.

Which I suppose is the result of an industry
getting a bit too super cas about archiving

its history and just letting things drop out
of memory like milk bottles from a poorly
supervised factory production line.

If you can only preserve one thing, preserve
the fucking PS2 era, for god&#39;s sake.

When the big developers could still indulge
out-there ideas before the industry was infected

with a terminal case of big money and turned
itself over to exclusively making milking

machines that they can&#39;t even be bothered
to paint in interesting colours - come on
Yahtzee, super cas, remember, eat the Twix.
Oh alright.
Heyyyyy.
Let&#39;s retro review.

Katamari Damacy was a quirky Japanese game
from 2004, and there&#39;s no quirk like Japanese
quirk.
Gosh the Japanese are quirky, aren&#39;t they.
Just look up Unit 731.
Even Japan&#39;s atrocities are quirky.
Hey, that&#39;s not where a human arm goes!
Anyway.

Katamari Damacy is about the King of all Cosmos,
a very serious-faced man with a swiss roll

for a head and a fondness for unsettlingly
tight leggings, getting a little bit too super

cas one day and destroying all the stars in
the cosmos.

Fortunately this can be remedied because the
King can create new stars from clumped together
balls of random quirky bullshit.

And double fortunately today just happens
to be random quirky bullshit clearing out

day down on Earth and everyone&#39;s fucking ankle
deep in the stuff, so the King&#39;s son, the

Prince of all Cosmos, has to come down and
steal all the random quirky bullshit using

a magic sticky ball that can suck up anything
smaller than it.

Yeah, I&#39;ve got some magic sticky balls for
ya.

Katamari Damacy&#39;s greatness lies in the simplicity
of its concept and the unrivalled catharsis
in its execution.

You start off with pathetic laughable sticky
balls that can just about pick up drawing

pins and which get gleefully batted about
by the cats that patrol the living room, but

then a few minutes later after you&#39;re done
hoovering up the garden furniture you come

back and there&#39;s something very rewarding
about seeing an exclamation mark appear above
the head of a cat that once bullied you.
I see you remember me, Mr. Whiskers.

After all, what good are sticky balls if you
can&#39;t crush pussy.

Shortly things get completely out of hand
and you move onto rolling up people, then

cars, then buildings, and eventually continents
and Godzillas.

Presumably an awful lot of people die horribly
when those katamaris get turned into stars,

but hey, there&#39;s nothing quite so super cas
as a few consequence-free murders.

Boy, Yahtzee, you sure have opinions on Katamari
Damacy, you must have played it a lot back
in the day.

You might want to put tea strainers over your
ears, listener, because this will blow your
mind: I&#39;d never played Katamari Damacy before.

The one I played a lot of was We Love Katamari,
the sequel, but it runs on the same engine
and plays identically.

It was doing the Hand of Fate 2 thing - same
game but with more stuff, which is fine but

it does render the original obsolete, and
that makes me question Reroll&#39;s decision to
only rerelease the first game.

I know precisely why they didn&#39;t do We Love
Katamari instead, it&#39;s because the plot of

We Love Katamari is literally &quot;let&#39;s make
a sequel to Katamari Damacy&quot;.

It&#39;s all very self-referential and ooh quirky
quirky Japanese Unit 731 unanaesthetized live
vivisection etc.

But it does mean that We Love Katamari doesn&#39;t
really work by itself.

Still, they could have easily remade both
the games into one package, like they did

with Crash Bandicoot and Spyro and those people
in the Human Centipede.

Playing the first Katamari Damacy alone I
feel disappointed by its comparatively slim

variety of levels and gameplay modes, and
I think it suffers from being a bit overgenerous
with the time limits.

On one late game level I&#39;ll have sucked up
the entire fucking town into my sticky balls

and still have about three minutes to roll
around the empty valley looking for every

last remaining brick and dustbin and thinking
up even more oblique ways to talk about my
testicles.

The time limits in We Love Katamari are a
lot tighter and even if you pass the King

of all Cosmos will talk shit about the size
of your sticky balls if you show up with anything

that wouldn&#39;t immediately silence all conversation
in the men&#39;s locker room.

Which is good because challenge is important
for catharsis.

The success of victory is all the sweeter
when there&#39;s a clear and looming presence
of failure.

That&#39;s why it&#39;s important to have a few ugly
bridesmaids at a wedding.

Katamari is quite challenging on the base
level because you control your sticky ball

in the same sense one controls an overloaded
shopping trolley with one dodgy wheel around
a car park.

See, that&#39;s what I didn&#39;t get out of Donut
County.

That&#39;s right, it&#39;s a Donut County review now,
that&#39;s the kind of thing that happens in super
cas videos.

Donut County was an indie game from last year
that had a similar vibe to Katamari except

instead of a big sticky ball which gets bigger
as things attach to it, like what makes sense,

you get a hole that moves around and gets
bigger as more things fall in it.
And how does that work, Donut County?

Does every single loose object in this town
carry a little pickaxe?

Are we supposed to believe this is some kind
of magic hole for wizards?
Why is everyone stupider than me?

In any case, amusing as it is to watch a cat
fall down a hole with a stupid look on its
face, after that the cat&#39;s gone.

Whereas in Katamari the cat is still there,
stuck to the side of your ball kicking its

legs in fury, and you can continue taking
the piss out of it.
And that&#39;s why Katamari&#39;s much better.

Donut County has its merits, it&#39;s got a stronger
story aspect, but it has no challenge so it&#39;s

a one-and-done, two hour distraction, where
Katamari&#39;s meatier gameplay and jaunty soundtrack
makes it almost endlessly replayable.

Besides, who&#39;d want a hole when you can have
sticky balls, am I right, fellers?
I&#39;m very lonely.
